update.description:
Changes required to run Gazebo with DART 6.

There are still 3 test failures related to DART which may need to be addressed or skipped for DART. The test failures don't seem to suggest anything too severe, but they point out some inaccuracies. This PR is a place to discuss what to do with these tests.

### Test failure 1. JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce (and same for JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset)

The cubes are meant to be "held up" by the force set to the joints. When viewing with gzclient, the behaviour is exactly the same as with ODE, it's working as expected. However the force and torque of wrench01 fluctuate quite significantly ([-35..35], sometimes more or less), while they are expected to fluctuate only in the range [-2..2].  The fluctuations aren't smooth, they sometimes incur large jumps between iterations.

Maybe the DART reaction to setting the force does not have an effect as immediate/accurate as with ODE, leading to the PID controller having to continuously adjust a higher error. Though movements are still too small to see in gzclient.

### Test failure 2. JointTestScrew.ScrewJointForce

The exceeded tolerances are not that high (max 0.0036 on my system, tolerance is set to 1e-08), and seem to only affect the position, not the rotation. Maybe just allowing a higher tolerance for DART in this test will suffice? Though it could be an issue related to the other two test failures.

### Test failure 3. JointTestScrew.WrapAngle

The velocity error starts off small but adds up significantly over time. This consequently affects the error in the angle as well after an initial delay. This could maybe be related to test failure 1 as it seems to be related to setting the force. It seems to be applying too much force as the velocity increases faster than expected.
update.title: Dart 6

content.raw: Absolutely, it's the right way to do it. I must honestly admit that I didn't go through the whole list of models (obviously, hmrmm), so thanks for testing this properly and digging up these two issues.
content.html: Absolutely, it's the right way to do it. I must honestly admit that I didn't go through the whole list of models (obviously, hmrmm), so thanks for testing this properly and digging up these two issues.

content.raw: Oh yes, I meant that now I was able to run Gazebo, spawn a Turtlebot and the simulator is still running. Given the limitations of the physics engine with respect to multiple parent joints, I consider it a success, we can't do much more about it. I agree that changing the model not to rely on multiple parent joints if it does not need them is a solution, but the point of warning on physics engine limitations and keep the applications running is IMHO the correct thing to do.
content.html: Oh yes, I meant that now I was able to run Gazebo, spawn a Turtlebot and the simulator is still running. Given the limitations of the physics engine with respect to multiple parent joints, I consider it a success, we can't do much more about it. I agree that changing the model not to rely on multiple parent joints if it does not need them is a solution, but the point of warning on physics engine limitations and keep the applications running is IMHO the correct thing to do.

content.raw:
Well, the turtlebot (and other with multiple parent joints) won't really work, the models aren't properly added because DART doesn't support them. But the simulator doesn't crash and only prints an error. That's probably what you meant, I assume?
For the turtlebot, the multiple parent joints are a model design flaw, it doesn't really need it. We should separately consider to update the model accordingly maybe.

I also found the bug in DART. It was a bit of a pain to find because it didn't happen in debug mode - I've put a lot of extra checks in the code which I have to clean up before submitting a PR to dart 6. But it's confirmed it was a DART issue, not a Gazebo issue: A tangent with zero length in dart's ``ContactConstraint::getTangentBasisMatrixODE()`` was normalized and produced NaN values, which propagated down a long chain of function calls. DART should probably not produce 0 length contact normals to start with, but that could be another issue to follow up on. Anyway, that's definitely separate to this PR.
content.html:
Well, the turtlebot (and other with multiple parent joints) won't really work, the models aren't properly added because DART doesn't support them. But the simulator doesn't crash and only prints an error. That's probably what you meant, I assume? For the turtlebot, the multiple parent joints are a model design flaw, it doesn't really need it. We should separately consider to update the model accordingly maybe.

I also found the bug in DART. It was a bit of a pain to find because it didn't happen in debug mode - I've put a lot of extra checks in the code which I have to clean up before submitting a PR to dart 6. But it's confirmed it was a DART issue, not a Gazebo issue: A tangent with zero length in dart's ContactConstraint::getTangentBasisMatrixODE() was normalized and produced NaN values, which propagated down a long chain of function calls. DART should probably not produce 0 length contact normals to start with, but that could be another issue to follow up on. Anyway, that's definitely separate to this PR.

content.raw: the build looks good to me
content.html: the build looks good to me

content.raw:
Got the FCL bug: The bounding volume of one of the nodes has nan values so it doesn't work to find the minimum spanning bounding volume between two nodes. See  [fcl/broadphase/hierarchy_tree.hxx](https://github.com/flexible-collision-library/fcl/blob/fcl-0.5/include/fcl/broadphase/hierarchy_tree.hxx#L282) and you'll know what I mean: ``min_it1`` and ``min_it2`` have to be initialized before the double-loop.
The nan BV could be a problem which arises with the model, or in FCL before the tree building, but either way this is a bug that needs to be fixed in the FCL HierarchyTree. I will post a PR to fcl for this.

Meanwhile, I started another [jenkins build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia_docker/12/) with the last commit (fixes to avoid assertion failure with multiple parent joints).
content.html:
Got the FCL bug: The bounding volume of one of the nodes has nan values so it doesn't work to find the minimum spanning bounding volume between two nodes. See fcl/broadphase/hierarchy_tree.hxx and you'll know what I mean: min_it1 and min_it2 have to be initialized before the double-loop. The nan BV could be a problem which arises with the model, or in FCL before the tree building, but either way this is a bug that needs to be fixed in the FCL HierarchyTree. I will post a PR to fcl for this.

Meanwhile, I started another jenkins build with the last commit (fixes to avoid assertion failure with multiple parent joints).

content.raw:
The problem is that the TurtleBot (and also found the same for PR2) have multiple parent joints. DART can't do multiple parent joints - each ``BodyNode`` (basically corresponds to a link) is created simultaneously with one joint as a pair, and can have only one other parent ``BodyNode``.

At the very least for this PR the simulation shouldn't crash because of this assertion and instead should print a more descriptive error saying that the model is not supported. I've added this.

It is still a little awkward that the model can still be seen in gzclient, but that's just the way things are set up right now. At some point it would be nice to be able to return an error upon loading models through the factory message (i.e. make it a service). Aside from this, so far neither ``Model::Init`` nor ``Model::Load`` have return values for indicating success - if they fail, the model should not be added to the world in any way at all, to make things nice and clean. But that would be for a separate PR.

Now at least the simulator doesn't crash any more.

With the iRobot Hand it's a separate issue. The segmentation fault occurs in FCL (``fcl/broadphase/hierarchy_tree.hxx`` line 298), triggered by the DART world update (``dart::simulation::World::step()`` called from within ``gazebo::physics::DARTPhysics::UpdatePhysics``). There will be something about the model which triggers this case. I'm tracking this down now and will let you know when I found something.
content.html:
The problem is that the TurtleBot (and also found the same for PR2) have multiple parent joints. DART can't do multiple parent joints - each BodyNode (basically corresponds to a link) is created simultaneously with one joint as a pair, and can have only one other parent BodyNode.

At the very least for this PR the simulation shouldn't crash because of this assertion and instead should print a more descriptive error saying that the model is not supported. I've added this.

It is still a little awkward that the model can still be seen in gzclient, but that's just the way things are set up right now. At some point it would be nice to be able to return an error upon loading models through the factory message (i.e. make it a service). Aside from this, so far neither Model::Init nor Model::Load have return values for indicating success - if they fail, the model should not be added to the world in any way at all, to make things nice and clean. But that would be for a separate PR.

Now at least the simulator doesn't crash any more.

With the iRobot Hand it's a separate issue. The segmentation fault occurs in FCL (fcl/broadphase/hierarchy_tree.hxx line 298), triggered by the DART world update (dart::simulation::World::step() called from within gazebo::physics::DARTPhysics::UpdatePhysics). There will be something about the model which triggers this case. I'm tracking this down now and will let you know when I found something.

There are still 3 test failures related to DART which may need to be addressed or skipped for DART. The test failures don't seem to suggest anything too severe, but they point out some inaccuracies. This PR is a place to discuss what to do with these tests.

### Test failure 1. JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce (and same for JointForceTorqueTest.GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset)

### Test failure 2. JointTestScrew.ScrewJointForce

content.raw:
I've been given a final try to the pull request. Dart seems to work fine with simple models created with the model editor. However if I try some complex models like the iRobot Hand (it crashes the whole simulator) o the TurtleBot that throws:

`gzserver: /home/jrivero/code/gazebo-jennifer/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTJointPrivate.hh:59: void gazebo::physics::DARTJointPrivate::Initialize(): Assertion (this->dtJoint)&&("dtJoint is null pointer.\n")' failed.`

I assume that these are limitations to the integration of DART and we want to merge this PR with them, even if they crash the simulator?
content.html:
I've been given a final try to the pull request. Dart seems to work fine with simple models created with the model editor. However if I try some complex models like the iRobot Hand (it crashes the whole simulator) o the TurtleBot that throws:

gzserver: /home/jrivero/code/gazebo-jennifer/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTJointPrivate.hh:59: void gazebo::physics::DARTJointPrivate::Initialize(): Assertion (this->dtJoint)&&("dtJoint is null pointer.\n")' failed.

I assume that these are limitations to the integration of DART and we want to merge this PR with them, even if they crash the simulator?

content.raw:
Same thing happens with bullet and simbody (the latter prints a stack of errors too).

Kinematic links are not supported with DART yet (also not in previous dart-5), see also warning in [DARTLink::SetKinematic](https://bitbucket.org/JenniferBuehler/gazebo/src/dd4cadeb3f9b21ad8433792a73c2b220ffb04fd6/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTLink.cc?at=dart-6&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTLink.cc-884) (doesn't get called but is an indicator for lacking support). 

I agree that we should leave the support for this for a later improvement.
content.html:
Same thing happens with bullet and simbody (the latter prints a stack of errors too).

Kinematic links are not supported with DART yet (also not in previous dart-5), see also warning in DARTLink::SetKinematic (doesn't get called but is an indicator for lacking support).

I agree that we should leave the support for this for a later improvement.

content.raw: the `roof` link falls in the wind_demo, which is different from ode. i noticed that it is [declared a kinematic link](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/e0036a34fdab757971fa56d4b75612bd96f8b3a3/worlds/wind_demo.world?fileviewer=file-view-default#wind_demo.world-35) and maybe dart doesn't support kinematic links? At any rate, it looks like an improvement over the support for this world in dart5, so I wouldn't block this PR over that.
content.html: the roof link falls in the wind_demo, which is different from ode. i noticed that it is declared a kinematic link and maybe dart doesn't support kinematic links? At any rate, it looks like an improvement over the support for this world in dart5, so I wouldn't block this PR over that.

I've seen the first message (about the OnPoseChange()) but it's not severe and this has probably nothing to do with the problem you are having.

The first warning however makes sense: self-collision is currently disabled (see also comment by JS above from 2017-03-23)... could the problems you are getting be related to self-collision?

content.raw:
I think it would be nice to fix it in this PR... only if it turns out to be separate issue (e.g. unrelated issue with DART itself) I would suggest to handle it via an issue.

I have a few other things pop up on my TODO list that are pretty urgent before I get time to look at this again, but it shouldn't be long (probably on the weekend).
Meanwhile, if you can find a bit of time to keep testing, that would be awesome of course :) If there are any other issues, I can then handle them all in one go.

Thanks for testing this!

content.raw:
Oh, my bad. I replaced all the occurrences of the dynamic casts as JS suggested, but in this one case the assert wasn't appropriate, as the `collision `  can actually be `nullptr ` . That's why there wasn't an assert there in the previous version. I should have paid more attention…

I've started [another build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia_docker/9/) after fixing up all the latest comments on this PR, and changed this instance in `CreateShape ` to the old version. We'll see if this error happens elsewhere too, I've replaced the dynamic\_cast in quite a few places.
content.html:
Oh, my bad. I replaced all the occurrences of the dynamic casts as JS suggested, but in this one case the assert wasn't appropriate, as the collision can actually be nullptr . That's why there wasn't an assert there in the previous version. I should have paid more attention…

I've started another build after fixing up all the latest comments on this PR, and changed this instance in CreateShape to the old version. We'll see if this error happens elsewhere too, I've replaced the dynamic_cast in quite a few places.

content.raw: Missing doxygen in some methods in this class. The Gazebo style convention for a getter method is to remove the `Get`prefix. Could you rename this function to `ShapeNode()`? Also, it could be a `const` function. You can extend this comment to the rest of the Private classes in this pull request.
content.html: Missing doxygen in some methods in this class. The Gazebo style convention for a getter method is to remove the Getprefix. Could you rename this function to ShapeNode()? Also, it could be a const function. You can extend this comment to the rest of the Private classes in this pull request.
